skill.name: scientific-writing
skill.description: Core skill for the deep research and writing tool. Write scientific manuscripts in full paragraphs (never bullet points). Use two-stage process: (1) create section outlines with key points using research-lookup, (2) convert to flowing prose. IMRAD structure, citations (APA/AMA/Vancouver), figures/tables, reporting guidelines (CONSORT/STROBE/PRISMA), for research papers and journal submissions.

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill containing only documentation and guidance text. No executable code, scripts, network calls, file system access, or environment variable reads detected. All content is educational reference material for scientific writing.

content.value_statement: Transform your research into polished, journal-ready manuscripts. This skill provides step-by-step guidance on IMRAD structure, citation formatting, figure design, and compliance with reporting standards like CONSORT and PRISMA.
actual_capabilities: Structure manuscripts using IMRAD format (Introduction, Methods, Results, Discussion)
Format citations in APA, AMA, Vancouver, Chicago, and IEEE styles
Create effective figures and tables following journal standards
Apply reporting guidelines (CONSORT, STROBE, PRISMA) for different study types
Adapt writing style for specific disciplines and target journals
limitations: Does not perform actual data analysis or statistical calculations
Does not access external databases or citation repositories
User must provide their own research data and findings
Does not submit manuscripts to journals on your behalf

use_cases.title: Manuscript Preparation
use_cases.description: Draft and polish research papers for peer-reviewed journal submission with proper structure and citations.

use_cases.title: Thesis and Dissertation Writing
use_cases.description: Structure thesis chapters using academic conventions and format references correctly.

use_cases.title: Clinical Study Reporting
use_cases.description: Prepare clinical research following CONSORT guidelines and medical journal requirements.

prompt_templates.title: Draft Introduction
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me write the Introduction section for my research paper on [topic]. Follow IMRAD structure. The study examines [research question] and I need to establish context, identify gaps, and state objectives.

prompt_templates.title: Format Methods
prompt_templates.prompt: Review and improve my Methods section for a [study type] study. Ensure sufficient detail for replication. Include subsections for Study Design, Participants, Procedures, Statistical Analysis, and Ethical Considerations.

prompt_templates.title: Apply Citation Style
prompt_templates.prompt: Convert my reference list to [APA/AMA/Vancouver/IEEE] format. Here are the source details: [list citations]. Ensure correct in-text citation format and reference list entry structure.

prompt_templates.title: Journal Submission
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me adapt my manuscript for submission to [journal name]. Check title conciseness, abstract format requirements, section word limits, figure specifications, and required statements (ethics, funding, conflicts of interest).

output_examples.input: Write the Results section for a randomized controlled trial comparing a new diabetes treatment to placebo. Include data on HbA1c reduction, adverse events, and participant retention.
output: ‚Ä¢ Primary outcome: HbA1c reduced by 1.8% in treatment vs 0.4% in placebo (p<0.001)
‚Ä¢ Secondary outcomes: Fasting glucose, BMI changes reported
‚Ä¢ Adverse events: Similar between groups (treatment: 23%, placebo: 21%)
‚Ä¢ Statistical methods: ANCOVA adjusted for baseline values

best_practices: Write in complete paragraphs with flowing prose rather than bullet points except in Methods sections
Use past tense for Methods and Results, present tense for established facts and your interpretations
Include complete, self-explanatory figure captions with sample sizes, units, and statistical annotations
Verify all citations against original sources and follow journal-specific formatting requirements
anti_patterns: Leaving bullet points in the final manuscript (except for specific Methods cases like inclusion criteria)
Overusing jargon without defining terms for your target audience
Mixing tenses inappropriately or using inconsistent terminology throughout
Duplicating information between text and tables/figures instead of highlighting key findings

faq.question: Which AI tools support this skill?
faq.answer: This skill works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code for drafting and revising scientific manuscripts.

faq.question: Does it handle specific citation styles?
faq.answer: Yes. It covers APA, AMA, Vancouver, Chicago, IEEE, ACS, and NLM styles with detailed formatting guidance.

faq.question: Can it help with figure and table design?
faq.answer: It provides guidelines for creating publication-quality figures, choosing visualization types, and formatting tables to journal standards.

faq.question: Is my research data kept private?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill only processes what you share in the conversation. No data is stored or transmitted externally.

faq.question: Why should I use prose over bullet points?
faq.answer: Scientific journals require flowing prose for most sections. Bullet points are only appropriate for lists like inclusion criteria or materials in Methods.

faq.question: How does this differ from reference managers?
faq.answer: This skill guides writing and formatting decisions. Reference managers (Zotero, Mendeley) handle citation collection and formatting automation.
